question: Will Julian Assange receive a pardon before April 1, 2025?
reasoning:
Based on the gathered information, here are some key points relevant to the question of whether Julian Assange will receive a pardon before April 1, 2025:

1. **Trump's Position**: Donald Trump has indicated that he would "give very serious consideration" to pardoning Julian Assange. Trump is set to retake the presidency in January 2025, which gives him the authority to issue pardons. He has a history of using presidential pardons, having pardoned 144 people during his first term.

2. **Legal and Political Context**: Julian Assange has been convicted under the Espionage Act, and there is significant advocacy from civil liberties and human rights organizations for a pardon, emphasizing the case's threat to press freedom. The U.S. Department of Justice and Julian Assange reached a plea deal, which has been criticized for its impact on press freedom.

3. **International and Domestic Advocacy**: There is significant international political support for Assange, with more than 60 Australian politicians signing a letter in support of him. Prominent free press and human rights groups have sent a letter calling for the U.S. to drop charges against Julian Assange.

4. **Timing and Decision Making**: Trump's spokesperson stated that he will make pardon decisions on a case-by-case basis. Assange pleaded guilty to charges of publishing military secrets in June, which may influence Trump's decision.

Given these factors, while there is a possibility that Trump could pardon Assange, the decision is likely to be influenced by political considerations and the broader implications for press freedom. The timing is also critical, as Trump would have to act quickly after taking office in January 2025 to issue a pardon before the April 1 deadline.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.3

AP Photo/Pascal Bastien

His prosecution is over, but the implications for journalists are alarming.

After pleading guilty to charges brought by the U.S. Department of Justice, Assange is the first person to be convicted under the Espionage Act for speaking with a source, receiving classified documents, and publishing them. In other words, things that journalists at news outlets do every day.

This is why [Freedom of the Press Foundation (FPF) led a coalition](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/08/us/politics/julian-assange-indictment.html) of virtually every major civil liberties and human rights organization in the country to denounce the unprecedented case as a clear and present danger to press freedom.

title: Everyone Donald Trump has said he might pardon
author: Theo Burman

hostname: newsweek.com
description: Trump is about to retake control of the presidential pardon, and he's already indicated who could receive one from his new administration.
sitename: Newsweek
date: 2024-12-02
categories: ['Politics']
tags: ['Donald Trump', 'Pardon', 'Joe Biden', 'Julian Assange', 'Peter Navarro']
---
[President-elect Donald Trump](https://www.newsweek.com/topic/donald-trump) is set to retake the reins of power in January 2025, and he's already indicated several people who could benefit from a presidential pardon.

President [Joe Biden](https://www.newsweek.com/topic/joe-biden)'s [pardoning of his son Hunter](https://www.newsweek.com/president-biden-pardon-hunter-biden-1993866), despite promises not to do so, has thrown the power back into the spotlight. Reserved exclusively for the executive branch, presidential pardons can be completely unconditional, and can forgive the recipient of any number of crimes, except in cases of impeachment.

Trump is no stranger to the power of pardon. Like most other presidents, he used it consistently throughout his first term in office, pardoning 144 people before his departure from the White House in 2020.

Since his announcement that he would run for president again, Trump has made several indications as to who he would pardon if he was returned to the presidency.

### The January 6 Rioters

Trump has made it clear that his top priority for pardons is the people who were most vocal in their support for him, even as President Joe Biden took power.

More than a thousand people have received charges for actions on January 6, which included riots, threats of violence, and breaking into the Capitol buildings, but Trump's team has said that the incoming president will approach the rioters on a "case-by-case" basis.

Karoline Leavitt, a spokesperson for the Trump transition team, and the incoming White House press secretary, told *Newsweek, *"President Trump will make pardon decisions on a case-by-case basis for those who were denied due process and unfairly targeted by the justice system."

### Peter Navarro

content.snippet:
---
title: Julian Assange
url: https://freedom.press/issues/julian-assange/
hostname: freedom.press
description: The prosecution and conviction of Julian Assange have alarming implications for all journalists.
sitename: Freedom of the Press
date: 2025-01-17
license: CC BY 4.0
---
AP Photo/Pascal Bastien

His prosecution is over, but the implications for journalists are alarming.

After pleading guilty to charges brought by the U.S. Department of Justice, Assange is the first person to be convicted under the Espionage Act for speaking with a source, receiving classified documents, and publishing them. In other words, things that journalists at news outlets do every day.

This is why [Freedom of the Press Foundation (FPF) led a coalition](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/08/us/politics/julian-assange-indictment.html) of virtually every major civil liberties and human rights organization in the country to denounce the unprecedented case as a clear and present danger to press freedom.

## Featured Items

-
[TikTok ban weakens First Amendment](https://freedom.press/issues/tiktok-ban-weakens-first-amendment-newsletter/)Plus: Biden must pardon Julian Assange

-
[Rights organizations demand Biden pardon Assange](https://freedom.press/issues/rights-orgs-demand-biden-pardon-assange/)Pardon would lessen the harm to press freedom caused by WikiLeaks founder's Espionage Act prosecution

-
[Incarcerated journalist and FPF guest columnist speaks out](https://freedom.press/issues/incarcerated-journalist-and-fpf-columnist-speaks-out/)FPF joined journalist Jeremy Busby on the Project Censored Show to discuss retaliation against journalists behind bars

-
[Justice Dept. and Julian Assange reach plea deal in case that threatens press freedom](https://freedom.press/issues/justice-dept-and-julian-assange-reach-plea-deal-in-case-that-threatens-press-freedom/)Freedom of the Press Foundation comments on the implications for press freedom of Assange plea deal

-
[Assange decision should be wake-up call for US](https://freedom.press/issues/assange-decision-should-be-wake-up-call-for-us/)America was once recognized as a leader in press rights. Now other countries question its commitment to the First Amendment

-
[UK grants Assange extradition appeal — but US can end this case now](https://freedom.press/issues/uk-grants-assange-extradition-appeal-but-us-can-end-this-case-now/)Freedom of the Press Foundation comments on the implications for press freedom of today’s Assange ruling

-
[Am…

content.snippet:
---
title: Everyone Donald Trump has said he might pardon
author: Theo Burman
url: https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-pardon-list-hunter-biden-jan-6-rioters-1993917
hostname: newsweek.com
description: Trump is about to retake control of the presidential pardon, and he's already indicated who could receive one from his new administration.
sitename: Newsweek
date: 2024-12-02
categories: ['Politics']
tags: ['Donald Trump', 'Pardon', 'Joe Biden', 'Julian Assange', 'Peter Navarro']
---
[President-elect Donald Trump](https://www.newsweek.com/topic/donald-trump) is set to retake the reins of power in January 2025, and he's already indicated several people who could benefit from a presidential pardon.

President [Joe Biden](https://www.newsweek.com/topic/joe-biden)'s [pardoning of his son Hunter](https://www.newsweek.com/president-biden-pardon-hunter-biden-1993866), despite promises not to do so, has thrown the power back into the spotlight. Reserved exclusively for the executive branch, presidential pardons can be completely unconditional, and can forgive the recipient of any number of crimes, except in cases of impeachment.

Trump is no stranger to the power of pardon. Like most other presidents, he used it consistently throughout his first term in office, pardoning 144 people before his departure from the White House in 2020.

Since his announcement that he would run for president again, Trump has made several indications as to who he would pardon if he was returned to the presidency.

### The January 6 Rioters

Trump has made it clear that his top priority for pardons is the people who were most vocal in their support for him, even as President Joe Biden took power.

More than a thousand people have received charges for actions on January 6, which included riots, threats of violence, and breaking into the Capitol buildings, but Trump's team has said that the incoming president will approach the rioters on a "case-by-case" basis.

Karoline Leavitt, a spokesperson for the Trump transition team, and the incoming White House press secretary, told *Newsweek, *"President Trump will make pardon decisions on a case-by-case basis for those who were denied due process and unfairly targeted by the justice system."

### Peter Navarro

Trump's former trade adviser, who joined his administration in 2017, served a four-month prison sentence after being found guilty of contempt of [Congress](https://www.newsweek.com/topic/congress). Navarro, who defied a congressional subp…

{"url": "https://freedom.press/issues/julian-assange/", "snippet": "---
title: Julian Assange
url: https://freedom.press/issues/julian-assange/
hostname: freedom.press
description: The prosecution and conviction of Julian Assange have alarming implications for all journalists.
sitename: Freedom of the Press
date: 2025-01-17
license: CC BY 4.0
---
AP Photo/Pascal Bastien

His prosecution is over, but the implications for journalists are alarming.

After pleading guilty to charges brought by the U.S. Department of Justice, Assange is the first person to be convicted under the Espionage Act for speaking with a source, receiving classified documents, and publishing them. In other words, things that journalists at news outlets do every day.

This is why [Freedom of the Press Foundation (FPF) led a coalition](https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/08/us/politics/julian-assange-indictment.html) of virtually every major civil liberties and human rights organization in the country to denounce the unprecedented case as a clear and present danger to press freedom.

## Featured Items

-
[TikTok ban weakens First Amendment](https://freedom.press/issues/tiktok-ban-weakens-first-amendment-newsletter/)Plus: Biden must pardon Julian Assange

-
[Rights organizations demand Biden pardon Assange](https://freedom.press/issues/rights-orgs-demand-biden-pardon-assange/)Pardon would lessen the harm to press freedom caused by WikiLeaks founder's Espionage Act prosecution

-
[Incarcerated journalist and FPF guest columnist speaks out](https://freedom.press/issues/incarcerated-journalist-and-fpf-columnist-speaks-out/)FPF joined journalist Jeremy Busby on the Project Censored Show to discuss retaliation against journalists behind bars

-
[Justice Dept. and Julian Assange reach plea deal in case that threatens press freedom](https://freedom.press/issues/justice-dept-and-julian-assange-reach-plea-deal-in-case-that-threatens-press-freedom/)Freedom of the Press Foundation comments on the implications for press freedom of Assange plea deal

-
[Assange decision should be wake-up call for US](https://freedom.press/issues/assange-decision-should-be-wake-up-call-for-us/)America was once recognized as a leader in press rights. Now other countries question its commitment to the First Amendment

-
[UK grants Assange extradition appeal — but US can end this case now](https://freedom.press/issues/uk-grants-assange-extradition-appeal-but-us-can-end-this-case-now/)Freedom of the Press Foundation comments on the implications for press freedom of today’s Assange ruling

messages.content:
{"url": "https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-pardon-list-hunter-biden-jan-6-rioters-1993917", "snippet": "---
title: Everyone Donald Trump has said he might pardon
author: Theo Burman
url: https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-pardon-list-hunter-biden-jan-6-rioters-1993917
hostname: newsweek.com
description: Trump is about to retake control of the presidential pardon, and he's already indicated who could receive one from his new administration.
sitename: Newsweek
date: 2024-12-02
categories: ['Politics']
tags: ['Donald Trump', 'Pardon', 'Joe Biden', 'Julian Assange', 'Peter Navarro']
---
[President-elect Donald Trump](https://www.newsweek.com/topic/donald-trump) is set to retake the reins of power in January 2025, and he's already indicated several people who could benefit from a presidential pardon.

President [Joe Biden](https://www.newsweek.com/topic/joe-biden)'s [pardoning of his son Hunter](https://www.newsweek.com/president-biden-pardon-hunter-biden-1993866), despite promises not to do so, has thrown the power back into the spotlight. Reserved exclusively for the executive branch, presidential pardons can be completely unconditional, and can forgive the recipient of any number of crimes, except in cases of impeachment.

Trump is no stranger to the power of pardon. Like most other presidents, he used it consistently throughout his first term in office, pardoning 144 people before his departure from the White House in 2020.

Since his announcement that he would run for president again, Trump has made several indications as to who he would pardon if he was returned to the presidency.

### The January 6 Rioters

Trump has made it clear that his top priority for pardons is the people who were most vocal in their support for him, even as President Joe Biden took power.

More than a thousand people have received charges for actions on January 6, which included riots, threats of violence, and breaking into the Capitol buildings, but Trump's team has said that the incoming president will approach the rioters on a "case-by-case" basis.

Karoline Leavitt, a spokesperson for the Trump transition team, and the incoming White House press secretary, told *Newsweek, *"President Trump will make pardon decisions on a case-by-case basis for those who were denied due process and unfairly targeted by the justice system."

### Peter Navarro

Trump's former trade adviser, who joined his administration in 2017, served a four-month prison sentence after being found guilty of contempt of [Congress](https://www.newsweek.com/topic/congress). Navarro, who defied a congressional subp…

messages.content:
Based on the gathered information, here are some key points relevant to the question of whether Julian Assange will receive a pardon before April 1, 2025:

1. **Trump's Position**: Donald Trump has indicated that he would "give very serious consideration" to pardoning Julian Assange. Trump is set to retake the presidency in January 2025, which gives him the authority to issue pardons. He has a history of using presidential pardons, having pardoned 144 people during his first term.

2. **Legal and Political Context**: Julian Assange has been convicted under the Espionage Act, and there is significant advocacy from civil liberties and human rights organizations for a pardon, emphasizing the case's threat to press freedom.
